captions.text:
This has nothing to do with physics, but you
know how sometimes kitschy shops have signs

where "the" is spelled with a "Y"? Ever wonder
where that came from? Ancient runes.

When people started writing in old English,
the sounds [þ] and [ð] were represented

by a symbol called thorn. As in, "thorn-O-R-N".
The use of a digraph, that is, two separate

letters, to represent thorn was only introduced
by the French and their crazy "way-more-letters-than-necessary-spellings"

So English scribes started using "T-H" to
spell newfangled French words like "theatre",

"Esther," and "neanderthal", and in the meanwhile
became sloppier and gradually stopped writing

the top part of thorn out of laziness. So
when printing presses started showing up in

England in the late 15th century and their
European typefaces didn't have stamps for

the letter thorn, creative printers decided
that "Y" was close enough, plus it saved them

one letter's worth of valuable space over
the more state-of-the-art "T-H". Thus, they

would abbrev. "the" as Y-E, "that" as Y-T,
"this" as Y-S, and so on, like this excerpt

from the mayflower compact, or "ye olde philadelphia
mint."

And that's where "the olde shoppe" spelling
comes from… so when you hear people pronounce

Y-E as "yee", you might want to remind them
that "ye" in old english means "you all"…

and as cool as it is, I'm not sure "y'all
old shop" conveys the "Merry Old England"

comments.text:
+Gren O' Wrackenderry Correct, Euch is still used, and is plural. It is 
just no longer used as the formal "You" singular as it was several hundred 
years ago, and was replaced with "Sie".

Like a King would ask of his Thegn, "Wann seid Euch gekommen" - "When did 
you arrive?" Or even earlier, "Wanne sîd Iuch gëkummen"
comments.author: Patrick Koren

comments.text:
And euch is actually still used in German, surviving alongside Sie- 
although Sie is now just a formal "you", and "euch" is a plural "you", if 
my memory serves me correctly.
comments.author: Gren O' Wrackenderry

comments.text: +Patrick Koren Yep. That's correct, Patrick.
comments.author: Gren O' Wrackenderry

comments.text:
+Gren O' Wrackenderry Ye is the nominative second person plural (second 
person singular formal), descending from Old English "ġē". In the 
accusative, dative and genitive you'd have: ēowiċ, ēow & ēower.
Ēow survived into the oblique (nom/acc) "you" that we use today, forcing 
"ye" into archaism. Ēower survived into "your". "You" during middle english 
was used thus for formal encounters and "Thou" was used pretty much the 
same it always had been. Euch (related to You/Ēowiċ) was also used in this 
way archaically in German before the use of Sie.
comments.author: Patrick Koren

comments.text: No problem! :)
comments.author: Gren O' Wrackenderry

comments.author: Otherones5

comments.text:
He's saying that using "Ye" in the place of "The" wasn't used until after 
the printing press. Particularly in the late 1700s. The word "ye" (our 
modern-day "you") has been used for a long, long time before- coupled with 
"thee", having its roots in the Germanic "Sie". :)

comments.text:
You, thou, dou, du / Have/have/habe/hast

Like in yorkshire they say ''Thou is/are'' or atleast some people do if 
they speak in a really old fashioned manner. Or you might hear ''thou is'' 
abbreviated to thou's, which sounds more like das. Like example; thou/dou's 
a great pal /You are a great friend.

It's also fairly rough accent. Moderrn-ish english accents don't have the 
guts of the old fashioned conservative worker's mentality of WW2 in their 
speech. I find it most interesting how nobody points out the similarities 
of ''thou'' to that of Dutch, German and Swedish's ''du''. If you listen to 
Yorkshire's version of ''thou'' it sounds like ''dou'', it can be 
interpreted as another variant of ''du''.
comments.author: John West

comments.text:
+Serai3
The concern of rather "you" evolved out of "thou" has already been 
addressed and corrected within this thread of discussion, and no parties 
here have further pushed or propsitioned that to be the case.

Also, Linguistically - when refering to stations - the best terms would 
either be "Formal" or "Informal".

They are also not "expressions" nor are they "conjugations". Conjugations 
deal only with the varying forms of Verbs. Elsewhere, they are Word 
Declensions, which are governed by Grammatical Gender and Case. Both "You" 
and "Thou" have their own Declensions. As in "Thou" being Nominative, 
whereas - modernly - "Thee" serves both Accusatively and Datively (from 
accusative "þec" and dative "þé").

For pertainant information and future reference I have here the histories 
of both words with some tid-bits:

You:
Anglo-Saxon (Old English) ēow, īow [dialectial], which is the Dative 
Declension of "ġē", Modern "Ye". English being a Western Germanic language, 
ēow descended from a Western Form of Proto-Germanic, "izwis" giving, 
"iwwiz" [ju:wiz/ju:wis] which was the Dative Declension of Western 
Proto-Germanic, "jīz" which descended from an earlier, "jūz". This latter 
word, being "You-Plural or You-Formal", was eventually birthed from the 
Proto-Indo-European root, "yūs". Ye is the Nominative Plural of "Thou".

The Full Declension of Ye is as follows:
Nominative: ġē
Accusative: ēowic [cognate to German, Euch], ēow
Genitive: ēower (Modern, Your)
Dative: ēow

Thou:
Anglo-Saxon (Old English) þú (You-Singular(-Informal)). This descended from 
Proto-Germanic, "þú" (Gothic: þu, Old Saxon & Old Frisian & Old Dutch: thū, 
Old High German: dū, Germand & Dutch: du, Old Norse & Icelandic: þú, 
Faroese: tú, Swedish & Danish & Norwegian: du, et al.) 
This PGmc word came from the Proto-Indo-European root, "túh2" (Albanian: 
ti, Irish: tú, Scots Gælic: thu, Ancient Greek: sú, Sanskrit: tvám. 
Bengali: tumi, Hindi & Urdu: tum, Kurmanji Kurdish: tu, Old Persian: tuvam, 
Farsi: tu, Pashto: të, Latin: tū, et al.)

The Full Declension of Thou is as follows:
Nominative: þú
Accusative: þéċ (Modern, Thee)
Genitive: þín (Modern, Thine & Thy)
Dative: þé (Modern, Thee)

There also existed Dual Forms (Indicating use by or for only two persons) 
that are no longer in use.

Nom: ġit
Acc: inċit, inc
Gen: inċer
Dat: inċ

Interestingly enough, with i > u; in some cases through-out Middle English 
(bisig > busy), probable Modern forms of these could be: Yut, Unk, Unker & 
Unk. Depending on Dialectial origin you could also have: Yit, Ench, Encher, 
Ench.

Hope this information is valuable.
comments.author: Patrick Koren

comments.text:
"You" did not evolve out of "thou".  They are both expressions of the 
second person conjugation.  "Thou" was used for people of lower station, 
younger people, or people with whom one has an intimate relationship.  
(That's why it's used towards God in the bible - because that was 
considered an intimate relationship.)  "You" on the other hand, was used 
for people of higher station, older people, and strangers.  It was a very 
neat and convenient arrangement, since the word used not only denoted 
station, but also the speaker's opinion of the person being spoken to.  
Saying "thou" to someone who merited "you" was quite an insult, and it was 
worth your head to say it to royalty, no matter who you were.
comments.author: Serai3

comments.text:
+Israel Lai +Suiseiseki Desu +Tilnaor I know this is an old topic, by the 
word "you" descends from the Old English word, "éow". The "y" is a later 
rendition because of Late Old English pronunciations of "éow" as, "íow" or 
"jó". In of which during the Great Vowel Shift, "ó" fell mostly into 
becoming a "oo" sound. Add in Norman French forms of pronunciation in 
Middle English and you get, "you." 

"éow" is related to the German word, "Euch" and just like Euch it was a 
formerly formal address to a single person, and standard address for a 
group of people; éow in the accusative was "éowic" [ye:o:ich/yo:ich] 
(German Medieval texts will display Euch in this manner).

Thou is related to German "Du" and both descend from Protogermanic, Þú.
comments.author: Patrick Koren

comments.text:
+Suiseiseki Desu  It culd have been something like the other German 
(Indo-European) languages the formal and informal (German: formal - Sie, 
informal - du)
comments.author: Tilnaor

comments.text:
As far as I'm aware, thou and you existed side by side.  Like the video 
says, the letter y existed at the same time as thorn, and was just used as 
a quick cheat.

Thou (Þou) was the informal singular (similar to 'tu' in French, tú in 
Spanish or 'du' in German)
You was the formal singular ('vous' in French or 'usted' in modern 
Castilian Spanish)
You was also the informal singular ('vous' (fr) and 'vosotros' in Spanish)
And finally the formal singular ('vous' or 'ustedes')

Despite thou/Þou seeming more formal to us now, due to how old it is, it 
was the informal like I said, and we probably kept the formal 'you' because 
a) thorn was falling out of use, b) it already covered the majority of the 
second person.
comments.author: HikariLicht

other languages descend as well (in Russian it’s ‘ty’, in Hindi it’s ‘tum’, 
in Persian it’s ‘tu’…).
They’re called Indo‑European languages and their latest common ancestor is 
called Proto‑Indo‑European. There are no written sources of it, but it’s 
been partially reconstructed with the comparative method.

comments.author: Lucijan Cernelic

comments.text:
No. As in many other European languages, English used to have different 
forms for the 2nd person based on politeness. If you wanted to be polite, 
or show deference, you would use the plural ‘you’ instead of the singular 
‘thou’. As we know English people are very polite, so they used ‘you’ so 
much that ‘thou’ eventually disappeared entirely. Also remember that people 
in the past used to read and write much less than today and literacy rates 
were much lower, so it would have been harder for a pronoun to disappear 
due to orthography alone.
And finally, thou and you are just the nominative forms. The oblique and 
genitive forms ‘thee’, ‘thy' and ’thine’  look quite different from the 
plural oblique and genitive forms ‘ye’, ‘your’ and ‘yours’.
comments.author: Clair Marchesani (Chiara)

comments.author: 温祺伟

comments.text:
Bad point.

I don't think 〈th〉 (where it usually represents voiceless dental fricative 
/θ/) is pronounced [tʰ] (voiceless aspirated alveolar stop) anywhere in 
Yorkshire, except in local varieties of Indian English, which is obviously 
not a reflection of North Germanic roots. I'm not sure what you're getting 
at with "twerk" but that joke plays on the tendency to strongly reduce the 
vowel in the word "to".

The Thorn rune represented a voiceless dental fricative in Old English, Old 
Norse, Proto-Norse and even Proto-Germanic (we think). Sound changes in 
most West Germanic languages (e.g. German, Dutch) resulted in a modern [d] 
(e.g. DE/NL: "danken" versus EN: "thank") while in most North Germanic 
languages the modern sound is (usually) [tʰ] (cognate in NO/DK: "takk" SV: 
"tack"). Icelandic, like English, preserves the fricative [θ], and in their 
case, the spelling with〈þ〉(cognate in IS: "þakka"). The fricative is the 
older sound in Germanic languages: it underwent fortition to [tʰ], and 
then, in continental West Germanic languages, sonorization to [d].

The pesky Normans actually would have used a stop (something like [t]) for 
anything spelt 〈th〉 (e.g. modern FR: "théâtre"). This is because it 
descended from Latin, which used a 〈TH〉 digraph to represent [tʰ] in, 
originally, words borrowed from Greek (cognate in LA: "THEATRUM", EL: 
"θεάτρων"). I wouldn't like to make a definite statement here, but I don't 
think any Romance language has ever used /θ/.

The spelling 〈th〉for [θ] in English derives from the changes in Greek 
phonology: when Greek [tʰ] lenited to [θ] (the opposite of what happened in 
Germanic languages), the Latin digraph suddenly made sense as a 
representation of Germanic [θ] as well.

This was a bit long, and possibly a bit involved, so in summary: 
contemporary North Germanic languages used dental fricative [θ] and 
represented this with the rune Thorn. When the Latinised Thorn was 
introduced in Old English, it represented the same sound. And the Normans 
had nothing to do with it.
comments.author: sealbones

comments.text:
So if it bothers you that Ye should be pronounced 'the' but is instead 
pronounced 'Yee' why do you not seem to have a problem pronouncing the word 
You as "Yuu" instead of 'thou' as it was meant to be pronounced?﻿
comments.author: Seadalgo

comments.text:
"You" wasn't meant to be pronounced as "thou". "You" came from Old English 
"eow", which was (and still is, really) the dative form of the 2nd person 
plural pronoun. "Thou" came from "Thu", the 2nd person singular nominative. 
Back then, if you're referring to one person, it's "thu, thec, thin, 
the"(thou, thee, thine, thee), and if you're referring to more than two 
people, it's "ye, eowic, eower, eow"(ye, you, your, you).

Some time after Shakespeare, the plural pronouns became the polite way to 
address people, and the singular pronouns became rude words to use, similar 
to how they developed in other European languages like German and Russian. 
The singular forms are still used in dialects spoken in Northern England 
and Scottish lowland.

comments.text:
P.S. I disrespect french, not because they're often insulted for playing 
bad in some games, but I can't understand what they are saying when they 
talk in english due to their accent & the way they remix their words. In 
Pokemon After season 8.. I think season 10-13, in several episodes there is 
this french woman & I can't understand anything no matter how many times I 
replay the speech audio. Also in the commedy series "Step by Step" when 
Cody got removed after season 4 or 5.. then came this french man & I could 
barely understand what he said, let alone laugh at it, it made me want to 
laugh even less, whether funny or not. The only thing that I sometimes find 
fascinating is "ze" because "the" is a overused english word, I find it 
both good & bad/annoying, depends I guess :). Mmm I might get a lot of 
haters for typing against the French, just saying my opinoin though - but 
does anyone else agree to some of it :O?

comments.text:
btw, the word "gateau" takes a circumflex accent, because it comes from 
ancient French "gastel", => the S and the L have been removed => the a 
takes a "^" and the "l" is repleaced by "au" => gastel -> gâteau﻿
